fields.descriptive_line: Card board game, Greyhound Racing, published in England in the 1930s
fields.physical_description:
Design: double folded card with a chromolithograph showing 4 tracks 
No. of squares: 100
Squares illustrated: 6
Square numbering: all
Squares titled: start, winning post
Subject of starting square: start
Subject of ending square: winning post
fields.dimensions: Height: 31.5 cm, Width: 62.2 cm, Height: 33 cm box, Width: 28.5 cm box
fields.title: Greyhound Racing
fields.public_access_description:
Sporting activities have inspired many games, most of which follow the designs of older games. Horse racing, and in particular steeplechasing, gave rise to a new design of playing board. This is often folded in three rather than two. The playing surface is long and oval-shaped, and the playing spaces are narrow and angled. The basic rules of race games are still used however, with turns missed and players moving backwards and forwards as directed.

In this game greyhounds take the place of horses. It is played in a slightly different manner, because the hare must be advanced on its own track at the same time as the dogs. This is achieved by using two dice of different sizes, the smaller one for the hare. The dogs are moved by the players individually when their turn comes round, but the hare is moved at each throw of the dice. The metal dogs and hares were made by Britains Ltd, a company famous for their lead figures.
fields.history_note:
Although very similar to other steeplechase games, it is played in a slightly different manner as the hare must be advanced on its own track at the same time as the dogs.  This is achieved by using 2 dice of different sizes; the smaller for the hare.  The dogs are moved by the players individually when their turn comes round, but the hare is moved at each throw of the dice.

CGG - GAMES & PUZZLES, 1991
fields.historical_context_note:
Rewards: winning
Forfeits: missed turns
No. of Players: 3 +
Equipment required: 3 lead dogs wearing racing jackets ( black & green, white & brown, brown & blue)
1 lead hare, tan
2 dice of different sizes, standard bone  marked 1-6; wood marked 1& 2

Rules:
To win, a dog can either land in the same compartment as the hair or pass the winning post, but the dogs may not pass the hare, and those that might, lose a turn.  Losing a turn is also the penalty if a dog lands in a compartment already occupied as `it is supposed a fight ensues'.  
The playing surface shows an oval track which is divided into 4 running tracks and numbered 1 to 86 with 87 to 100 doubling with 1 to 14.  The outer track is for the hare and the inner 3 tracks for the dogs  In the top corners are illustrations of dogs and in the bottom corners illustrations of hares.

GREYHOUND RACING
As many players can take part as there are dogs.
The hare does not belong to any player, but is moved by each player every time a dog is moved, the game being won when a dog falls on the same division as the hare, or, in the event of this not happening, by the dog that reaches the Winning Post first.
There are two dice||||:  a large one containing numbers up to 6, belonging to the dogs and a small one containing numbers 1 and 2 only belonging to the hare.

RULES
Both dice are thrown together by each player.
For 3 players the dogs start at the Starting Place, while the hare starts at No. 8.
For 2 players the dogs start at the Starting Place, while the hare starts at No. 12.
First move the hare the number of points shown on the snall dice; then the dog is moved the number of points shown on the large dice.
Dogs cannot pass the hare.  If a throw brings a dog beyond th hare, the dog does not move, but remians where it is.
if a dog moves on to a hurdle number it must stay until the player throws an odd number, but the hare is moved every time.
If a dog falls on a division occupied by another dog, it is supposed a fight ensues and it loses a turn but the hare dice is thrown alone.
The game ends either by a dog fallin on the same division as the hare, or, if this does not occur, by the first dog reachig the Winning Post.

NOTE:  When the hare passes the Winning post, only throw the large dice for the dogs.

Rules placement: pasted to the inside of the lid
